Award.AwardTitle: Langlands Correspondence, L-functions and Automorphic Forms
Award.AbstractNarration:
Local Artin root numbers whose existence were established by Langlands and Deligne (in some cases earlier by Dwork) are crucial objects in establishing the local Langlands correspondence between n-dimensional continuous representations of the Weil-Deligne group over a local field F and irreducible admissible representations of GL(n,F). In fact, a unique correspondence is obtained only after the root numbers and L-functions attached to tensor products of representations of Weil group are shown to equal to those defined by Rankin product factors for corresponding representations of two GL(.,F). There are some other instances where these objects are defined for representaions of GL(n,F) such as exterior square and symmetric square representations of GL(n,C), as well exterior cube when n is less than or equal to 8 by means of the Langlands-Shahidi method. As the first topic in this proposal, the investigator will study a robust technique which can be used to prove the equality of these factors by those defined for Weil group through the correspondence. Techniques involved are a deformation argument as well as a generalized Shalika germ expansion for Bessel functions by Jacquet and Ye which seems to be amenable to generalization to other groups. He will also use Arthur's results in his upcoming book to resolve certain questions concerning the Langlands packet attached to an Arthur packet, as well as certain arithmetic questions (Weyl laws) for classical groups, and their generalizations to general spin groups. Computing the residues of intertwining operators for classical groups in terms of endoscopy which he has been pursuing in collaboration for many years, should also benefit from Arthur's character indentities which he will explore as part of this project. He will also study certain representation theoretic consequences of functoriality. Next he will continue his joint work on studying p-adic L-functions through the Langlands-Shahidi method, and pursue Langlands new ideas on Beyond Endoscopy and Reciprocity, as well as the possible generalization of the method to loop groups and covering groups.

The proposal involves training of graduate students and postdocs and includes specific problems for them. The investigator expects several new students to join him and other members of the Number Theory group at Purdue and is involved in teaching high level courses (e.g.,p-adic L-functions, automorphic forms, representation theory of real Lie groups) to train them. Theory of Artin L-functions and its connection with reciprocity law (correspondence) of Langlands is one of the most beautiful parts of number theory which the investigator hopes can be studied by students of different level in different seminars. On another level, he is involved in organizing conferences as well as serving in editorial boards of several prominent journals as well as panels. Moreover, he remains involved in mentoring and minority hiring and currently serves on the Department's Graduate Recruitment Committee with emphasis on recruiting women and minority students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Number theory is well-known for problems which are easy to state and hard to solve. For example, Fermat's last theorem which states that, if n > 2, then there are no triple of non-zero integeres where n-th power of one equals to the sum of n-th powers of the other two, something that Fermat thought he had a proof of but couldn't fit in in the margins of a book he was reading about it! It took mathematicians more than three hundred years and finally a proof of it was given by Andrew Wiles from Princeton University by very advanced and complicated techniques which have now led to many advances in number theory and arithmetic geometry. Among the techniques used in the proof are those coming from Langlands Program, a vast collection of problems and conjectures, named after Robert Langlands, an emeritus professor at the Institute for Advanced Study at Princeton, NJ, who initiated it. The problems studied in this project are mainly rooted in this program and have applications to number theory and arithmetic geometry, as well as automorphic forms where Langlands program is all about.

One of the major results of the proposal concerns reciprocity laws in number theory which are part of Langlands program. They set up reciprocities between two sets of objects of very different nature. In the case in hand one of the two sets is that of representations of Galois groups which are of arithmetic nature, while the other consists of representations of local groups which are analytic objects. The reciprocity is to preserve certain functions attached to them,  namely root numbers and L-functions defined by completely different methods. While the reciprocity is established for GL(n) over any local field by Harris-Taylor and later by Henniart and Scholze, it is shown by them to preserve the Rankin product factors for GL(n) only. Our major result proves the equality of the factors for symmetric and exterior square L-functions for GL(n). Techniques involved are those of proving stability of these factors for supercuspidals under highly ramified twists, which benefited from ideas of Jacquet-Ye on germ expansions for Bessel functions. The proof is fairly complicated but well-praised by referees and will appear after revision in Duke Mathematical Journal.

Other results include the introduction of a p-adic measure to represent the inverse of a Dirichlet L-function by means of Fourier coefficients of the corresponding Eisenstein series on SL(2), i.e., through Langlands-Shahidi method. Moreover, while reciprocity for global number fields is completely out of reach, one can prove a consequence of it, the Principle of Functoriality which allows transfer of automorphic forms from one global group to another in certain cases. This is proved as part of this project between GSpin and GL(n) with full determination of the image.

The project also involved training of graduate students through their direct supervision as well as their training through graduate courses taught at Purdue. It also included expository lectures in China and elsewhere which have led to expository articles and a public lecture at SIU.
